Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: By taking chemistry 161 I learned a fair amount of chemistry that I did not even begin to touch in high school chemistry.  By taking this course, I also learned how to work in a lecture setting and succeed in a large class with little personal interaction with the professor.
General knowledge of chemistry, how knowledge can be applied.
Organization and problem solving skills were improved as were close reading from the textbook.
As the course suggests, Chem 161 offers a general foundation of chemistry and basic scientific principles. Not many skills were developed.
I developed a much better understanding of chemistry and this class definitely made me improve on my time management skills to make sure all my work was done on time.
I learned the basics of chemistry to use in future science courses.
I gained a good general understanding of general chemistry.

Important chemistry skills
how to do a lot of work ahead of time so it didn't pile up
Background on chemistry
I gained a comprehensive foundation in general chemistry.
I learned the basics of chemistry and how atoms make up the world around us. I studied the shape of an atom and it's orbitals, and how they interact with other atoms around them.

I learned how to study on my own because my professor did not do a good job teaching the course. He also blamed the entire class for doing poorly on the second exam and took no ownership that he placed two problems on the exam I nor many of my fellow classmates have ever seen before on any practice problem, book problem, or online problem.
I was able to master the topics in chemistry that will help me in my future academic endeavors in science here at Yale.
I learned a lot about the fundamental chemistry skills.
Basic chemistry (not really much else to describe the course).
Honestly nothing from the course itself or the professor. Everything I learned I did on my own or from my TA
General Chemistry and problem solving. Not much in terms of research or critical thinking.

I learned how to effectively self study because many topics were not sufficiently covered in class. The class helped me to think about real life applications of all the topics that were mentioned in the textbook.

Learned a lot about theories on the atom and various chemical formulas. The course was undoubtedly very educational/informative. Was inspired by the demonstrations and thought that science was cool.
Personally really not a fan of the COAST method...seems a bit juvenile and the same concept can be conveyed without using the acronym.
I enhanced my problem solving skills
I learned all about general chemistry and I felt I strengthened my skills in science overall.
I learned a lot about chemistry during this course. Coming from a background of almost no chem, I am surprised at how much about the subject I've absorbed.
Basic chemistry

Learned basic components of general chemistry; learned to use resources available (office hours, peer tutors, teaching fellows, etc) for help; learned using practice problems in the book or on lecture slides was key for success in the class
It is what you would expect out of a Gen Chem class.
Seeing as I came into the class with absolutely no chemistry background, I learned a lot of general chemistry. I gained some self-teaching skills as well.
It was a good introduction to chemistry. It did not go that in depth but introduced a broad range of topics.
Learned basic chemistry concepts.

I learned basic general chemistry which I had not been exposed to in highschool. Many people who had already taken AP Chemistry had already learned the material. The class improves your problem solving skills, and the lectures include real world applications of chemistry.
I learned a lot about how the world works and a lot of phenomena were explained. my math skills improved
lots of new chemistry

Chemistry 161 is great for building foundational chemistry knowledge. When taking this class, I hadn't been in a chemistry course since sophomore year of high school, but this course covers all of the fundamentals in a really easy-to-understand, methodical way. I also developed a lot of my science learning skills through this class.
This course helped improve my understanding of many of the fundamental concepts of chemistry.
I learned a lot of skills necessary for basic chemistry.
How to teach myself things outside of class
I learned more about the basics of chemistry more thoroughly.

Having taken AP Chem in high school, this class was very similar in terms of the topics that were covered, although this course went more in-depth and covered more material. I think it definitely helped that I took AP chem before this class because my high school level chem class would not have sufficiently prepared for me this class and would have made it much harder to grasp the topics.  Overall, this course helped me in developing a stronger chem foundation. It also helped me manage my time better and get into a routine because of its organized structure with set deadlines, assignments, and exams.
I learned how to take my learning into my own hands and keep up with the recommended reading and additional assignments.
This course provided a very comprehensive overview of chemical processes that provided many different forms of active learning and engagement to learn them over the course of the semester.
Gain a better understanding of Chemistry concepts than I ever did in high school.
I developed a basic knowledge of the first half of general chemistry. The class also seemed to emphasis applications and problem-solving which was helpful.
A general overview of necessary chemistry knowledge.
I learned a comprehensive overview of basic general chemistry principles.

I learned about chemical concepts along with some of their applications. I was able to form a strong understanding of concepts that involve the study of matter along with its transformations. It has given me the skills to analyze problems with chemical context. I also learned about the importance of time management.
I learned about various topics in general chemistry and applying math in my analysis of chemistry, which I found I really enjoyed.

Having only taken chemistry my sophomore year in high school, I learned a lot about chemistry in this course. In this course I learned about chemical elements, reactions, properties of elements and compounds, thermochemistry, gas laws, and metal structures.
I learned a solid foundation of basic chemistry and gained an understanding of how to apply knowledge in a college sciences setting.
I learned basic chemistry.
Learned a much deeper understanding of chemistry.
By taking this course, I developed basic chemistry skills that will provide a foundation in my future chemistry and premed studies.
I gained the skill of learning simply by reading the textbook

I learned the basics of a typical first semester Chemistry class, from atoms and molecules, through thermochemistry, solubility, and solids.  I also learned how to solve problems integrating all of these concepts, and some basic applications to climate change and materials science.

-how to critically analyze chemistry problems 
-learned the basic chemistry principles necessary for taking higher level courses
I gained a basic understanding of chemistry, further than material I learned in high school.

I learned so much information over such a vast array of topics--from thermodynamics to gas laws to even how atoms are arranged in metallic structures. This course is wonderful for first years who may not know how to approach a college class. This course has SO much structure and even guides students on how to be active learners.
I did not learn much skills from this class except how to cram for a final.
Basic chemistry topics.
How to teach myself.
I learned a great amount about Chemistry from the structure of an atom to lewis structures to freezing and boiling point depression.
I learned about different chemistry principles and foundational ideas.

I learned a variety of different solving techniques and ways to approach different problems. I also learned how to seek help outside of class and section, and I became very accustomed to time management with problem sets and other homework required by this class.

In this course I gained a solid foundation for how atoms and molecules interact with each other by studying different theories, models and laws. I learned to more rigorously apply dimensional analysis to solve an array of problems and understand every day phenomena thanks to a more solid chemistry background.

I took chemistry in high school and struggled with it, so I thought I was just naturally 'bad' at the subject. This class taught me that this isn't true. As long as I read, do the sample and practice problems in the book, do the practice problems online, really try at the clicker questions in class, take notes, etc., I can do well.
I was exposed to the first half of general chemistry.
This course was a great refresher of Chemistry as I had not taken it in over a year.
The ability to gather information, derive more information based on whats given, and use the info and analysis to work step by step to desired solutions.
I gained a pretty comprehensive understanding of general chemistry, and the course helped me learn how to keep track of lots of little assignments at once.
The course allowed me to develop my own learning style and gain a basic foundation of chemistry.
I feel that my critical thinking skills improved because of the difficult theoretical concepts taught in this course.
knowledge of general chemistry concepts
Good foundation in general chemistry
I learned the basics of Chemistry needed for premed and for further biochem courses.

How to perform in a big lecture.
How to learn by myself and take control of my learning process.
I developed a great understanding for general rules and topics of chemistry. It was a great introductory class and taught me much about the world around me.
I learned a lot of the basics of chemistry.
It was a lot more in depth that my high school classes every touched on. I learned a lot about the logic behind that math that goes into the subject as well as how to approach a problem.
I learned some foundations of chem
The information I learned in this course provided a foundational base of knowledge that makes me prepared for the second sequence of General Chemistry.
I learned problem-solving skills applicable to not only chemistry, but various aspects of academics and life. I learned how to analyze information and gained insight on chemistry concepts.
I learned more than a thorough foundation of the beginning of the science of chemistry. Furthermore, I learned how to study for a big college lecture.
I gained knowledge of basic topics in chemistry.

I learned how to truly appreciate chemistry. This course really allowed me to fully understand the concepts rather than just gloss over them like I did in Honors Chemistry in high school. I learned how to apply the concepts I learned to higher level problems.
I learned the general concepts of Chemistry in this course necessary for my potential major and prerequisites for medical school.
I strengthened my problem solving skills and ability to apply the concepts learned in real-world situations.
Knowledge in basic chemistry, problem solving, and attention to detail.
This class helped better my understanding of chemistry. The problem sets prepared us very well for the midterms and final and overall I think the course was structured well.
This class taught the fundamental aspects of chemistry. From significant figures to thermal chemistry and gas laws, a wide scope of chemistry was taught throughout this class.

The biggest insight that I developed by taking this class is that constant revision is the best method of learning. The course material was presented in such a way that I was constantly exposed to the concepts that were presented earlier in the chapter and even previous chapters. This encouraged me to take the revision process into my own hands. I also learned the importance of asking for help. The office hours and teaching fellows helped me make it through this course!
Gained a lot of knowledge in chemistry that I hadn't touched on since sophomore year of high school.
I developed a strong understanding of basic chemistry concepts and better study habits.
The skills I gained from taking this course will serve as a good foundation for the next science courses I will take while at Yale.
I learned a general understanding of chemistry and its basics.
I learned basic principles of Chemistry which allowed me to foster a general foundation for the subject matter.
You learn a lot of chemistry it was a fine class but if youve taken AP this class will be pretty easy for you with the curve I did not take the AP and all these people messed up the curve.
Basic understanding of fundamental chemistry concepts.
I developed knowledge on a broad range of topics in general chemistry. I feel well prepared for the second semester of general chemistry and future chemistry classes.
This class is an introduction to basic general chemistry and is a great foundational class for those that look to take advanced chemistry classes.
Basic knowledge on redox reactions, thermochemistry, lattice structures, and many other topics.

This course teaches the basic chemistry needed for not only the second half of the year sequence, but the knowledge gained helps to understand certain biological functions that you learn in other natural science classes.
I developed a familiarity with basic concepts and methods of chemistry, and I learned to work through simple chemical problems.
I learned an in-depth knowledge of general chemistry as well as gained problem-solving skills.
I learned valuable information about chemistry.
The class covers basic concepts in chemistry, including characteristics of atoms, simple chemical reactions, and thermodynamics.

I gained skills to solve basic chemistry problems about matter and energy, atoms,stoichiometry, solution chemistry, thermochemistry, gases, molecular geometry, intermolecular forces, etc.
I learned a lot about how to study, and how to manage time.
I learned the basic principles of general chemistry in this course. These skills helped strengthen my foundations in the subject and will help me with next semesters work.
I developed good insight and knowledge on the basics of chemistry. Nonetheless, later chapters were not focused on rigorously.
Having a weak chemistry background before taking this course, I was exposed to many new models and concepts such as MO theory. The topics covered within this gen chem course were varied.
I learned much about General Chemistry and remedied many gaps Id previously had in my understanding of the subject from high school.
I learned a lot of information towards chemistry and how it factors into everyday life.
I learned about various topics in chemistry and developed my problem solving skills.
I gained a comprehensive knowledge of beginning chemistry.
I learned about the fundamental concepts involved in Chemistry.
This class was more of a holistic review of chemistry but I thoroughly enjoyed it.

I learned how to rely on my textbook for the majority of information in the course, due to the amount of curriculum and the short amount of time spent in lecture. I also learned how to problem solve when problems were unfamiliar.
I developed the ability to think critically on a more theoretical level.
I learned the basics of general chemistry.
I learned fundamental chemistry concepts.
I developed a greater understanding of the basic concepts of general chemistry.
General chemistry knowledge.
I learned the foundations of chemistry.
Basic knowledge about inorganic chemistry, reactions.
Introductory chemistry knowledge
More complete information typical of a high school Chem course
Much greater understanding of general chemistry and the elements of the periodic table.
I learned basic chemistry knowledge in topics such as thermochemistry, stoichiometry, and solubility.
This is the most comfortable I've been in chemistry in the entirety of my life.

By taking this course, I learned about basic chemistry concepts such balancing chemical equations and stoichiometry. I also learned about more complex concepts such as quantum theory and molecular orbital theory. The lecture emphasized the connections between what I learned in the book with everyday examples.

This course goes very fast and can be hard to keep up with if you don't have any chemistry background.  I had taken two years of chemistry in high school and still found myself getting lost and not doing very well on the exams.

I feel that the hour tests are a bit too long to complete in one hour. Perhaps an extra thirty minutes added to the time allotment would help. Also, it might help if the class was moved off of science hill. Prof. Holland was never able to start on time because many students had a difficult time making such a long trip to SCL in such a short time; this caused our class time to get cut by 5 to 10 minutes every class, which was really unhelpful.
Could do more with the more difficult topics and spend more time working through problems.
The course offers lots of resources so it is easy to do well.

A strength of this class was the environment of the class. Professor Holland definitely made it an enjoyable class to be in and I really like demos at the end of the classes. However, I feel like a weakness was that sometimes not enough time was spend in class explaining the harder topics.

The course was a great review of high school chemistry concepts with a little bit of new information at the end. The only weakness was that the class sessions did not include going through enough problems.
The course was very straight forward, but had difficult concepts past the first exam material. More examples and exam-like questions during lecture would greatly improve the course.

This course is very straightforward. The course is well organized and the objectives are clear. All of the necessary information is in the textbook. Lectures served mostly as a supplement to the textbook material, and can be helpful if you've prepared well for class. Not an amazing course but nothing obvious to improve.

A lot of material crammed into a short period of time; I thought the lectures weren't very helpful, or not as helpful as the discussion section. We would breeze by some material, but then it wasn't always easy to follow what material we did look at more in depth.
It was very student response driven for such a large lecture however it was sometimes difficult to pay attention for the long periods of time required

Strengths: lots of resources, tests and assessments are fair 
Weakness: sometimes only do random stuff in class rather than what's important

I appreciate that this class is no longer flipped classroom, but I found the time spent in the classroom to be boring and redudant. We were still expected to do the reading and come to class to have that reinforced. I often found that in class, the exact same things from the reading were being discussed and it was boring. It did not draw my attention or expand on my knowledge. I have several classmates who skipped all but a few of the lectures and still have the same grade as me in the class because they kept up with the readings. The lectures did not provide any incentive to go. Nothing was gained from the lectures, except maybe very small and specific pieces of information included on the exams as his way of tricking all the people who did not regularly attend class. The only side note to this is that the demonstrations were cool to see in class, but often I did not find them overly enlightening by themselves. I understand that they were there more to reinforce the knowledge, but sometimes I think they were just a waste because they were simple knowledge.
I love how Professor Holland makes a genuine effort to engage the class and make it more fun. However, the class could have provided me more practice questions for me to study on my own.

Strength--lots of help outside of lecture

However, lectures were a waste of time, and there seemed to be a development of a dichotomy between students who took chem before and those who haven't. This seems unfair.

Oftentimes the full class meeting was not extremely related to the practice problems or the exam questions. The discussion sections were sometimes helpful but other times the problems were way too simple or way to difficult. Overall, there was quite a fluctuation in the difficulty of assignments and expectations of the students but it was a good course and I have definitely learned a good amount about general chemistry.

This is a poorly structured course and I really struggled to learn. I think its wrong that the course is set up to assume that everyone has some baseline knowledge before they even walk in the door for the very first lecture. Then, you're expected to teach yourself the new material before each class (and be tested on it beforehand), which is just ridiculous. This also enables the professor to not teach by explaining that we should've learned it beforehand.

The strength of the course is definitely the consistency and the organization of the work. There are always practice problems to do, which forces the students to stay on top of things. A great first course for students new to college.

The strengths of this class was that we had many opportunities to practice our problem solving skills through interactive clicker questions. In additions, there were a lot of resources to help students outside the classroom. The main weakness of this class was that I didn't feel like I learned much in the classroom at all. The lectures moved too quickly for any information to be retained and portions that aren't relevant to exams were stressed for too long in one lecture. Falling behind on readings and not learning much in the classroom did not help my understanding in the class.

Strengths: provides a good chemistry background. 

Weaknesses: starts off really very slow in the beginning and then speeds up in the later half because students are introduced to topics they are unfamiliar with. Perhaps time distribution can be adjusted so that more time is spent on later concepts that are harder to understand.
Generally low level of engagement with the students .
Clicker questions take up an absurd amount of time.
While ChemTours are a good idea in theory, the price and the extra effort needed to actually watch them results in very very few students actually doing them. I don't know anyone who watches them.
Important concepts are sometimes brushed over during class, or explained in a very basic way that does not always correspond to the difficulty of exams.
This course did a really great job at helping learn the material! All of the peer tutors were really helpful and I really learned from them.

I think this class is very fast-paced, but I understand that there is a lot of material to go through. I think that all of the assignments are weighted pretty fairly, and that the workload is well-distributed.
A major strength of this course was my TA.

This class was not well suited for someone who has never had exposure to chemistry concepts before.  As someone who did not have access to this type of advanced science course in high school, the format and speed at which this class was taught was extremely distressing.  I understand that there is a steep learning curve that accompanies the transition from college to high school, but this course was extremely difficult to adapt to.

Strengths: Class demos that showed concepts, a lot of resources provided for help if needed
Weaknesses: Difficult to keep every student engaged (nature of lecture class); confusing when professor or TF would complete a problem wrong and we would run out of time in class
Good coverage of the basic concepts in chemistry.

I think the strengths of the course lay in the amount of resources given to us for extra practice and help. Though some people didn't have my luck, my TF was great. I also appreciated how much our practice problems and problem sets were taken into account for our final grade. 

However, there were several weaknesses with the course. For one, there were extraordinary disparities between the skill levels of the students taking the course. I, for instance, came in without taking any high school chemistry courses, but I know a significant portion of the class took AP, IB, or multiple years of chemistry and could have done well in higher leveled chemistry courses. Starting from scratch while so many others around you are already coming in with a wealth of knowledge is daunting. I feel like the instructor was aware of this, and despite the course being described as one for students with 0-1 years of chemistry knowledge, he seemed to assume some knowledge on our part that made several lectures hard to follow. 

The lectures themselves were a bit flawed. Timing-wise, I had a class on the other side of campus that started 15 minutes after chemistry was supposed to end, 11:20. As such, I needed to leave precisely at 11:20 to make it, which meant I sometimes missed the useful parts of lecture because the timing of the lecture was a bit off. In terms of format, I wasn't a fan of the flipped-classroom style. Though I realize that there's always an element of self-teaching when learning, I felt that I ended up teaching myself the vast majority of concepts. Several lectures, such as those on hybridization, VSEPR theory, MO theory, and even some stoichiometry left me more confused than when I went in to lecture. I hope future iterations of the course will try to explain these concepts more fully with fully worked-out examples.

I thought the information was presented very well and there were so many helpful resources available to all students. The class is just such a huge lecture which is something I dislike although I understand you cannot really avoid it.

The content was pretty well structured. Lectures were somewhat unhelpful, especially when the professor very obscure and specific examples instead of taking the time to thoroughly explain basic concepts.
The strength of the course is that it really does teach you a lot, but it does move quite fast. If you fall behind, you may have a hard time catching up.

It is a good class for teaching such a large lecture. The format with lecture, discussion, problem sets, and daily readings/practice problems/reflections force students to keep up with their work. However, since different TA's teach different sections, students with more engaging TA's have a significantly larger advantage because discussions teach the problems on exams.
lots of resources
I thought it was run really well.

The course is really well-designed in that all students are required to use "clickers" to check understanding and to boost class engagement. I also think that Professor Holland is really invested in making sure that all the students feel that they are participating in the course, since he holds lots of office hours and consistently gives his students feedback through Canvas emails. For a lecture course, the class is remarkably personalized and student-oriented.
The course is taught quite well and class meetings are interactive. There are office hours either with Professor Holland or a Teaching Fellow every day of the week, so getting help is easy.
This course is really good. The professor provides the students with so many opportunities to get help and the classes are really organized with the reading and weekly psets.
Making section mandatory so we have to practice problems and reinforce skills

The strengths of this course is that the professor provides students with a lot of resources that range from websites to office hours. The professor also does try to engage students by making connections and applications to real life, and demonstrates using experiments.

One thing I would like to see improved is the number of practice problems offered for students to use to study. Throughout the course of this semester, I found it difficult to study for the exams because the way the content is formatted is very different from that of the Sapling or textbook problems. I think more practice exams should be made accessible for students to be able to do more practice.

By far the weakest aspect of this course was the lectures. As the semester progressed, the lectures became more disorganized and confused. It was difficult to decipher what the overall objective of the lecture was and how it related to the assigned reading of the previous night. In all, there was a general consensus among students that going to lecture was a waste of time.

I really liked how the online practice problems helped students familiarize themselves and better understand the topics covered. However, I would have liked more practices tests to be available. I enjoyed the overall structure of the class as well: readings the night before class, practice problems, in-class lectures, clicker questions during class, practice sets for the chapter, three midterms, and a final exam. However, I often didn't do the readings the night before. This made it easy to be distracted during class and therefore, the in-class lectures weren't very useful for me. I also enjoyed the demonstrations that were done in class, but I often found them to be a little unnecessary and a waste of time, especially since class usually started late and we would run out of time to finish going through all the lecture slides.

The strengths of this course were in the number of resources provided to ensure the success of the students. The weakness of this course was the lectures. I didn't feel that I got much out of the lectures.

A strength of this course is the continued engagement with the material through the discussion posts and sapling homework/problem sets, assigned readings and recommended readings. The weakness is definitely lecture time. The class itself was not well organized and the relevant information was not presented in depth in class. Discussion section and the outside homework were much more useful.

This class's main strength was the large amount of resources provided to students that needed any help, and we repeatedly had opportunities to engage in the material through practice problems, discussion section, and in class material. If there was any weakness, it was simply that due to time constraints, we would have to continue at a rapid clip through the ongoing material while we were studying for midterm hour exams. I felt that in this period I was more distracted from the most recent material we were studying because I cared more about my understanding of the past material I would be tested on.

The class can be better structured. The lectures hardly touch upon concepts in the test. Since the test is heavily math focused and the lectures are information based, I find the lectures to be extremely unhelpful.

This course portrays itself as being paced for students with little to no background in chemistry, and at the beginning of the course, I thought this was the case. But as time progressed, it became clear that many other students in the class had several years of experience with chemistry, and as such, the professor increased his pace, leaving students with less experience behind.

The strengths of the course is how organized the coursework is. Everything is set out in front of students and finding the tools to learn is never difficult. The weakness of this course is the organization during lectures. We waste a lot of time during lectures going over what seems like tangential information or just seem to misuse a lot of time.
the course included very irrelevant information at times. more time should be used to cover the more confusing topics.
This course was very well organized and extra help was made very available to us. Professor Holland was a very clear lecturer and was very engaged with the course.

The strengths include that there are many practice problems available for practice and that there are many resources available for help. A weakness is that the material could be presented a little better.7th
Strengths: clear set-up and grading system, work distributed evenly during the semester, many resources to help students (made them very clear too)

The strengths of this course is that there is many opportunities for students to succeed in the class. There are office hours nearly everyday of the week and professor Holland sets up the course so that students have every opportunity to succeed and learn the material. The grading of the class is very direct and Professor Holland lays out the grading syllabus at the beginning of the class. The lowest of the three midterm exams gets dropped which is very helpful and allows students to do better in the class. Some of the weaknesses of the class is that there is a wide range of skill level of the students. Some of the students in the class have taken AP chemistry while others have never taken a chemistry class before. Another weakness is that the lectures are so big so it can be difficult to focus on the material.

The course provided many different kinds of assistance, through the help of TA office hours and peer tutoring. In lecture-style classes, it is very easy to lose track of material or fall behind. Having resources like class sections, TA office hours, and peer tutoring made sure I was always comfortable with the material.
The lectures could be more organized and helpful to learning. I did majority of my learning from the text book.
The strength is that there is a lot to learn and engage with but the way it is talk is choppy, scattered, and class times seem ineffective. It feels like I must learn everything on my own.

Strengths: very well organized, lots of effort put into the class, Professor Holland was a great instructor, class was designed to make sure you didn't fall behind, lots of effort was put into the teaching pedagogy.

I loved discussion sections for this course. I found them very informative and helpful, and they helped me to establish a better understanding of the course material. However, I did not like the flipped classroom environment. There was a lot of information that I still had trouble with after looking through the book and watching the chemtours, and I would have liked to run through sample problems as a class rather than through clicker questions.

I think the strengths are the textbook and sapling- I found them very straight forward, easy to follow, and helpful. One weakness was that the lecture just summarized what we read in the textbook instead of digging deeper or facilitating understanding. The size of the lecture made it too hard for people to really ask questions.

I had difficulty adjusting to the flipped classroom style this course was taught in but I learned how to teach myself the material from the textbook. Lectures were not extremely helpful, but they reinforced what we learned from our readings prior to each class. I think it would be more helpful if lecture material and textbook material were more directly related. However, psets and homework load were reasonable, and the discussion sections were pretty helpful in giving us more practice problems.

The course is well-paced and the combination of readings, lectures, Chemtours, practice problems, and problem sets really serve to reinforce the material.  There are a multitude of resources available to help you succeed if you choose to take advantage of them.

One major weakness, perhaps unavoidable, is that these many different means of reinforcing the material mean that the process of learning each chapter's content is scattered across many weeks.  Typically, we did readings, practice problems, and lectures on a given chapter from one Wednesday to the following Monday.  Then the discussion section would take place perhaps a few days after we had finished that chapter, and the problem set would be due in another week after we had already moved on to new topics.  By the time we took the exam for chapters 4-6, we were learning chapter 9 material in class.  This sometimes made it difficult to keep track of various material.

Strengths:
-presents material using a variety of different modalities (chemtours, textbook, sapling, etc.)
-in class clicker questions help aid learning 

Weaknesses:
-lectures are very inefficient 
-lab demos are cool but take up time 
-not enough practice tests

This course is way too easy to skate through for a "college" chem class. For the first 2 months, I coasted off of what I remembered from taking chemistry in my freshman year of high school (not AP). As time went on, it was still very easy to do the bare minimum in terms of learning content and still get excellent grades, especially because of how the class is graded. While I know more about chemistry now than I did before the semester started, I feel like I could have learned a lot more.
You could learn just as much from reading the textbook as going to lecture.

I liked the sapling, and the prep for the exams. 
I felt as though the lectures were not very useful, there could be more problem solving.

I feel I didn't have much of a reason to go to lecture, although it I understand that it is hard to motivate students to come to any lecture. With that said, I really like all the online study materials available via canvas!

The strengths of this course are that the material was spaced evenly and allowed time for self-study. The one weakness that I'd point out is that, while material wasn't lacking, more practice problems every day could have been assigned to ensure that students comprehend the textbook. The Sapling practice problems aren't as hard as the Problem sets which is frustrating. More homework more often would help.
strengths would be the clear organization of the class, the weakness would be the amount of interaction.
Lecture often feels pointless but often feels helpful so somehow finding a way to make every class worth going to.
Professor Holland brings a great positive energy. But many complex topics were not covered in depth enough. That's mostly a problem of time: there's too much that has to be learned too fast.

The course was very thorough and there was a large amount of outside help available when needed. The problem sets were very helpful in understanding the material that could be used for exams and the practice problems and reflections required before every class helped to ensure student comprehension.

The class is very well organized, with lots of opportunities for additional practice and help. The class is set up in a way such that it is very hard to struggle alone. Having said that, the material, in my opinion at least, was a little dry, and the lectures got more confusing towards the end of the semester.
Good organization, and class structure, only potential weakness is the reflections.  I thought those were a little unnecessary in some regards.

The strengths of this course are the discussion sections, especially Zachary Carter. It was a time to really learn and understand the problem solving behind concepts and the way to do the problems. However, the weaknesses of this course were the lack of time to do problems and actual computations as a group in class.

I liked the demonstrations in class and the clicker questions were useful to apply the lesson we had just learned. I would have liked to see more clicker questions/exam questions in class and be given a few minutes to solve them on our own before he professor goes over them in class. In fact, since Professor Holland covers the concepts we read in the textbook, I would have actually loved a flipped classroom where we would learn the concepts outside of class and just do clicker questions and demonstrations in class.

The lack of actual instruction was somewhat frustrating

The weekly sections were when I learned the most.

Strengths: Lots of opportunities for extra practice and help - even thought it's a big lecture class, I never felt neglected. Also loved the demos!

Weaknesses: I sometimes felt like if I had done the reading carefully, paying attention to the lecture slides wasn't completely useful.

The course could be improved greatly if the lectures did not go ahead of the test material. It's helpful to have a week or two between the last material and the test that it will be included on, but as a result, I couldn't pay attention enough to the new material being taught during that time. Instead of going through the new unit's material, review over the chapters would be a lot more beneficial instead of doing some review at the very end of the course when we finish material ahead of time before the final exam.

I felt like the actual lectures were not very helpful. I would leave feeling like I hadn't learned all that much. However, the discussion sections were where I really felt that I learned the most. My TA was extremely helpful in helping to explain the concepts. Perhaps making the lectures less frequent, for example one a week, and the discussion sections more frequent, for example twice a week, would be the most beneficial.

Going to class usually wasn't that helpful, Prof Holland always started class late and I found I didn't learn much while I was there. The textbook is super useful though and it was nice how aligned/linear the midterms were with the textbook (chapters 1,2,3 for first midterm, etc).

Weaknesses: Only one practice exam to use for each exam

Strengths: Lectures reinforceme material rather than introduce it, learning done mostly outside of class, good for those who are self driven.
I think this course was set up just fine, but it may require a lot of self-study if you haven't covered the material before.
The course is very well organized, but discussion sections and lectures could be more engaging.
The clicker questions were notary useful in helping me learn the content. I feel that more time should be spent actually going over concepts during lecture;

Strengths: covers basic material 
Weaknesses: class lectures don't fully cover material, need to spend lots of outside time to teach oneself

This is a freshman course. I was a senior in this course as an ABET mechanical engineering course and I dreaded it. However, many of the lectures were recorded and posted online so you don't have to go to class.

Pros: Incredible outside resources. Loved the setup of sapling and the reflections. Zachary Carter was an amazing TA. 

Cons: The lectures were fun and exciting, but I didn't learn anything more than I could have on Khan Academy.

Lectures are not very useful.
Problem sets are very useful.
Expectations are clear from the beginning.
Sometimes too much extra stuff and fun facts and not enough sample problems and explanations.

I think the strengths of the course were the constant practice we had for each class period and the outside questions to make us think deeper about the topics. I think the sections with the extra practice questions were a huge help in preparing for tests. I think the only weakness was that we only got one practice test which I felt made it difficult to get an idea of different types of questions that would be on the test.
I thought the course was easy to follow, but I think that lectures could have moved faster to cover more material.

The course did its best to get individual participation and opportunities to ask questions and submit feedback which I really appreciated.
It was just hard to pay attention when there are so many people in the room,
sometimes I would get confused, but there was no time to ask questions and the professor would already be on the next topic.
I think the course is suited well towards students who have a backbround and who are learning for the first time

I think one of the biggest strengths of this course this semester were the TAs. They were always incredibly helpful, patient, and willing to help you with the material. In addition to this, the Professor is a very clear and charismatic lecturer who knows how to handle such a big class. Professor Holland's use of the clickers and lecture questions really added to his class, and I felt he did achieve the goal of interactive learning within a big lecture.
The problem sets, lecture and discussion sections really complimented each other and lead to a thorough understanding of the material and preparation for the exam. The exams were usually fair and clear, but, in some cases, too long. 
I think lectures sometimes moved by too fast, or certain topics were not covered with enough detail, especially considering their later importance in Psets and the exams. I felt the lecture lacked a bit more explanations pertaining to theory, we often spent a lot of time watching the Professor explain his way through problems on the chalk-board. The class itself moves too fast. There were times when we were preparing for an exam on chapters 4,5, and 6. Working on a Pset for chapter 7, but listening to a lecture on chapter 8. It made lecture much less productive, and the daily sapling problems much less useful.

strength: in class lectures taught in close accordance with readings and assignments
weaknesses: midterms should be right after the end of a chapter is taught, not several weeks later

Strengths: solid foundation and connection between different forms of learning (ChemTours, textbook, practice tests)
Weaknesses: lectures themselves seemed redundant and did not seem to provide much value beyond what was already covered in the textbook
This course was very organized and easy to follow in terms of due dates and homework. However, this course was poorly taught.

A definite strength was my TA Zach Carter. He was so amazing and was a huge reason I had success in this class. A weakness of this class was that I felt that sometimes the lectures were a little irrelevant, especially if I understood the reading.

This class is a fairly difficult intro course, so know before coming into it that you will have to do the majority of the learning by your own effort outside of the class. I personally have learned that I do not benefit from large lecture classes. The lectures went too fast and did not help me at all in preparing for exams. This may in part have to do with the fact that I had never taken AP Chem in high school. I found that people who took the AP before benefitted much more from the style of the class than those who did not. I feel that another system to allow more individualized learning needs to be set up in order to benefit those in the bottom half of the class. There should be an option to take seminar style classes in addition to the lecture, just as it is done in Economics.

This course encourages you to spend a little time every day on chemistry, whether through answering short reflection questions or easy practice questions. This was the only course I took this semester that required this, and thus, I learned the information along the way instead of cramming.
The strength is the depth and breadth of concepts learned in the course but it is still difficult learning in such a large lecture hall.

This course is very active and engages the students. There are many different outlets of learning, including lecture, reading, problem sets, online practice, and practice problems, as well as interactive learning in class. These different styles make learning the material very well-rounded and easier to apply.

Could be more interactive, its too easy to get through the whole semester without reading the book because the psets don't necessarily require deep knowledge. The in class experiments made the class more interesting.
The course was structured well with weekly problem sets and nightly reflections and practice problems. The weakness however was the lectures did not help prepare us for the problem sets at all.

A strength of this course was the amount of information taught. It was not an overwhelming amount but it wasn't too little to make the course boring. A weakness of this course was the number of students present in lecture. Students would always leave lecture early, creating a distraction.

The biggest strength of this course is that it encourages constant revision. This level of revision helped me focus on the areas where I needed to ask for help and review the textbook. The office hours and discussion sessions gave me the opportunity to ask questions and work with people who explained the material differently. The biggest weakness of this course was the lecture section. I feel like I had the hardest time grasping the concepts because the class cut off on several occasions. We didn't go through some of the questions that were presented on the lecture slides and I sometimes left more confused.

I really hate lecture style learning because I feel like I am teaching myself all of the material by reading the text book. I understand that this is necessary, though, with the amount of people taking the course.

The homework assignments (practice problems and problem sets) were good practice for exams. However, it would be more helpful if we could also have more time to do practice problems in discussion sections.
Weakness: We were usually about three or four units ahead (as far as material we were learning in class) of what we were being tested on.

strengths: good lectures, helpful TAs
weaknesses: constan homework (saplings and reflections) was more busying than helpful and it was easy to forget to do
Its weaknesses regard the TA's, since not all of them are as invested as others.

You have a to read a lot in the textbook so it took a lot of time but if you go to lacture you should be able to connect dots pretty well. Also professor Holland doesnt write the answers to exam questions which is kind of annoying when studying for the final.
Interesting demonstrations to reinforce concepts. The professor would often go over time.
Strength was good organization. A weakness was that it took a long time to get familiar with the various components used in the class.
This course is very well organized and has a lot of student input. It is meant to be shaped by our concerns and professor Holland made a great effort to design a class so that everyone could excel.

Strengths: TAs were helpful, class demos were fun and engaging
Weakness: the lecture was not helpful at all, felt like I was wasting time going

Strength: If you complete the textbook practice problems and the problem sets online, they truly help for the exams because the exams are fair and are not designed to trick you. Clickers during class kept students engaged. 

Weakness: Lecture was a bit boring and the many chem demos, while entertaining, were not always the best use of time.

The lecture was structured well in reviewing and reinforcing concepts from the reading. I think the discussion sections were helpful, but they could be improved to increase student engagement. For example, it might be helpful to have certain discussion sections devoted to class discussion on a particular issue, in which the whole section works through a problem until they are comfortable with it.

This course does a good job of giving the student many resources in order to be prepared for exams with lots of practice. Daily reflections and practice problems keep students up to date on the material. Lectures, however, were not that insightful.
Some strength include learning a lot. Some weakness would be the size of the course.

I give Prof. Holland credit for being a good lecturer, for soliciting student feedback, and for offering a large number of resources to help students succeed. However, I have a number of concerns about the way the class was conducted.

-Instructing students not to work together on the weekly problem sets is very unusual for a STEM class and makes the homework less useful. STEM classes traditionally encourage students to work together because this improves their learning.

-The pace of the class was rushed, which resulted in a large amount of work being assigned and in some topics being covered superficially. Covering less material in more depth would improve the class.

-Assigning practice questions for each class and requiring student "reflections" on the topics covered is unnecessary. It is students' own responsibility to learn the material and grading them on this activity is not needed in college classes. While I understand that this has the benefit of offering easily available points to students, that can just as well be done by grading the class more leniently if the instructors want a generous grade distribution.

-Grading on attendance, which is what the clicker questions essentially were, is also unnecessary for college students since it is their responsibility to attend class.

-Grades were submitted after the deadline and on-time submission would improve the quality of the class.

A strength was that it required a lot of individual effort to figure out problem sets and stay engaged. 
Lectures were not that effective for learning for me. I learned best from the book.

Strengths of the class were discussion sections and clicker questions. During discussion section, there was a clear outline of what we were to do and the questions provided were always helpful in learning.
It could be improved by making the exams closer to the chapters they are testing. Also, using sig figs on Sapling would lead to a much better understanding of sig figs.

The strengths include the fact that a vast array of concepts are introduced allowing people not too familiar with chemistry to learn about the different areas. However, this also was a weakness as the course moved too fast and not enough time was spent on reviewing the harder concepts as needed. Furthermore, the problem sets on sapling and very lengthy and become confusing as there are no guided examples for the difficult questions; I was often completely unsure of how to approach problems.

I think it would help tremendously if the lectures aligned with the reading material more in terms of relevance. This was especially true leading up to exams, where we would be covering multiple future chapters the day before an exam of material covered long ago in lecture.
My discussion section was a huge strength, but I honestly felt that the way lectures were ran were a huge weakness. The lectures were disorganized and unhelpful.

I think the biggest strength of the course was that the class was very well structured; we were able to cover a lot of material, but it never felt like we were moving too quickly. Additionally, I felt that the format of the class was helpful because you had some understanding of what would be taught / knew what you didn't understand before you got to lecture. The main way I feel like the course could be improved is that because the lectures were only fifty minutes, especially if we did a lot of watching videos/ demos during that period, it felt like we didn't have enough time to be explicitly taught the material/
Lots of ways (interactive lectures, readings, problem sets, etc) to truly learn the course material.
The course has many resources for students to learn the material with which they are struggling. This is great for an introductory lecture course like this one.
The p sets were super helpful, I often looked at them when reviewing for tests.

I think that a weakness was the lectures. In the lectures, we covered more conceptual topics while the tests were very much problem solving centered. I think the course would improve if we solved test questions step by step and include the conceptual concepts by integrating them into the teaching of the math. A strength was the review sessions. I learned the most the two days before the test.
The  strengths of this course are the Sapling Learning website for homework since it is a very helpful tool when completing problem sets, and the canvas reflections and discussrions for extra help.
Class lectures are all promptly posted and online is very organized. Could be more engaging.
Large lecture size can be hard to learn in. But TAs were very helpful.
The lecture aspect of this course needs great improvement. Concepts were rarely ever explained in a clear manner. Moreover lecture was not super engaging.
Fewer but longer lectures would be better
Engaging professor and interesting material, the TFs are also helpful and are readily available.
Teacher is a very nice guy but I prefer using the textbook to learn.

I didn't find the clickers or reflection questions helpful. I don't agree with the clickers because I shouldn't be graded for my attendance, as long as I prove that I can learn the material otherwise. I did like the psets and section though, which helped me cement my knowledge in a low stress environment.

I think the set up of the course is well structured and reasonable. However, I highly suggest having more than one practice exam for each midterm and final. The practice exams provided did not really prepare us for the actual exam because it was a lot less difficult than the actual exam.

One strength of the course is that it is well-organized. Another strength is that the textbook does a good job at explaining most of the concepts we learn in class. One weakness of the course is that the lectures are often focused on everyday examples rather than on techniques on how to solve problems. Another weakness is that 50 minutes does not seem to be enough time to go over everything we read about in the book. More emphasis on the concepts rather than explaining their significance in the world could help fit more content into the 50-minute lecture.
I would recommend this class to someone who wanted to get involved in the science field.  Chemistry deals with the entire world around us and is very helpful to people interested in majoring in STEM.
This is a really great course that built upon my high school chemistry classes well. As a chemistry lover myself, I'd be insane not to recommend this class to anyone who is willing to take it.
Very good intro Chem course
I would recommend thus class for those who enjoy science because it really does help you expand your chemistry knowledge and prepare you for harder science classes.
I would recommend this course because it gradually eases you into college life while still teaching you.
I would recommend this course to another student if they need a QR and would like a course whose information will be useful to them down the road.
This course is likely being taken as a requirement in which case it's perfectly fine. If it's not a requirement I wouldn't recommend it as a course to take just for fun.
Yes, but only because it's a requirement. It was a fine class, but I didn't particularly enjoy it.
Yes it's well organized and taught, if a bit dry
Yes, definitely necessary for more advanced couses and provides good background in chem.

This is a very boring and basic introductory level course. There is no reason to take this course unless you are required to. The only perk to this class is holding fire in your hand on the very last day of class, and then the line for that is so long that you will have to wait a very long time.
Only if they have to take general chem to fulfill major requirements.
Yes, I recommend it because Professor Holland is a qualified and fun professor. But I think all STEM majors have to take this course anyway, so don't stress out. It's going to be great!
If pre-med.

It is your basic entry level chemistry class. If you've taken AP Chemistry in high school, I recommend taking something else since almost all of the material is the same. Professor Holland does a good job teaching it though and if you enjoy chemistry then it's a solid class.
It stinks because you have to take this class for many majors/premed requirements/etc, but its not a good course, and Yale could do much better with a class that SO many people have to take.

I would not recommend this course to another student. I took this class without needing to for my major, and while that was a good decision for me, I know most students would not enjoy that because it is a huge lecture class with pretty standard information. Nothing novel.
I would if it is a requirement for your major or career path.
I would recommend it only because you have to take it. As an introductory lecture course, it does well enough. Perhaps there are some aspects to such a huge class you just have to accept.
Yes, especially if you want to take an enriching science course.
Yes, but keep in mind that it is a very basic and slow introduction to chemistry.
The course is a great introduction to Chemistry. I would absolutely recommend taking it.
Yes, but I would strongly warn them of the speed at which concepts are taught and advise them to request a personal tutor as quickly as possible.

I would recommend Chem 161 to people who actually need to take it (pre-med, or thinking about pre-med, etc.). The material is necessary for moving on to higher levels of chemistry, but unless a student is genuinely interested in chemistry or needs to take it as a pre-req, I would not recommend it to just anyone looking for a spare class to take.
Yes, if you need to take it. I wouldn't take this course for 'fun.'
Yes. I mean I would definitely recommend it over CHem 163.
I would recommend this course to a student who is willing to spend time outside of class to learn the material themselves.
It's definitely a good class to take as an intro to chemistry; it's pretty easy if you've taken chemistry before. It also accompanies 134L pretty well.
Yes
I would only recommend it to a student who must take it for a credit.
yes i learned so much
Yes

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. All science students should have a strong fundamental understanding of chemistry, and this class definitely gives all of its student that basic knowledge. Also, the professor is great, and there are lots of fun demos throughout the course. I also just think that the material is pretty interesting, even though it's basic chemistry, since Professor Holland always gives us some real-world examples to work with and clicker questions to personalize the class.
I would recommend this course to students considering a major in the pure sciences. It's a prerequisite and also very well taught.
I would recommend this course for someone who is genuinely interested in learning about chemistry.
Not really, but it is a prerequisite for a lot of sciences, and you need it if you're going to be pre- med.

I would recommend this course to another student because it is definitely important to take for a foundation in chemistry. If you have taken AP chem is high school, this course is a great way to refresh your mind of the material that was covered and learn more in-depth about them.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student that was willing to put their learning in their own hands and take responsibility of their work.
Yes, I think the workload was very reasonable and the content is interesting. It's a broad introduction to Chemistry which is definitely a good subject to understand for many STEM related careers.
Yes this course provides a strong foundation for chemical processes that is very accessible for students who only took 1 introductory year of chemistry in high school.
Yes because a basic level of chemistry understanding is kind of essential, but not because the class is extraordinary or anything.
yes! patrick holland was a great professor!
I think if you want to learn Chemistry, this is good place to start.

I would recommend the course to another student, as it will help them create a basic understanding of chemistry that I believe will help provide a solid foundation before moving on to upper-level chemistry.

Yes, I really enjoyed taking this course. Even though the material was somewhat difficult, it challenged me in a good way. However, the workload was just the right amount to keep me on top of my work, but not make me feel stressed out.
I would only take this class if you have to for your major.

I would absolutely recommend this course. It is not very exciting content, but it is content that is necessary to pursue a wide range of STEM majors. It is fairly easy and Professor Holland makes class enjoyable.
I learned general chemistry which was good, except I pretty much learned it all from the textbook. But don't let that deter you, just keep doing the homework and reading and it's fine.
Yes, this course is standard for anybody who is possibly interested in a STEM field. Lot of work though, so make you stay ahead on it.
Absolutely not
I would definitely recommend this course to another student because I found it very informative and helpful for students who did not take AP Chemistry.
I would only recommend if they were considering pre-med or something in the sciences related to chemistry
I would recommend the course to students who have to take it as a prerequisite for major/pre-med.

You're probably considering taking this class because it's a prerequisite for something or required for your premed track of major.  In that case, I would recommend it, though I expect you'd take it anyway.  It is by no means the most painful requirement to complete for a STEM degree, it is not a class designed to "wash out the weak," it is genuinely possible for everyone to succeed.  

Professor Holland actually loves chemistry and tries very hard to impart that love to the students.  I did learn a lot in this course and further reinforced and solidified what I had learned in high school chemistry.  That being said, taking this course with no chemistry knowledge at all, or only a year of regular high school chemistry could be fairly challenging and require a bit of additional effort to take advantage of the extra course resources.

I would recommend CHEM161, but as it is a lecture course, I'd only suggest taking it if you must take it as a prerequisite. The subject material is not very interesting, unless you really enjoy chemistry. For me, it was a good test of my problem solving abilities.

Take this course if you have to i.e. if you are premed or a if it required for your major. You don't learn anything in this class that you couldn't on your own, and it is not an "interesting" science class.
It was a fine course, not very good, not terrible.
Not unless you have to take it, it isn't too difficult but I personally don't find chemistry to be fascinating. I suppose it does depend on your personal perspective though.

I would recommend this course because it is a requisite for many careers and higher level classes. I would simply warn them to study hard every day and keep up by giving themselves more problems to do ether form the book or online. It's not a bad class, it's just not as guiding as I would have liked.
Take the class if you have to, not if you just want to learn something new. You don't have to go to lecture, just go to discussion and read the textbook.
I wouldn't say this is the most interesting course but chemistry is a good subject to know and needed for many majors so it's a good class to take.
If not for a requirement, don't take it. If for a requirement, take it and get through it but be ready to spend a huge amount of time learning the concepts on your own and through Kahn Academy.
I only recommend this course if you are required to take it. It is a very strenuous course that should probably not be taken unless it has to be for pre-med or a major's requirements.

The material, though useful, is somewhat dry. If this is a prerequisite, take it. If you don't need to take the class, however, don't take it. There are probably more interesting--perhaps less important, however--science classes that you can take.

Take the class if you have to take it. It does what it can to help students who have never taken chemistry but it is still a heavy course with a lot of different topics. There is never a pause in this course.
I would not recommend this course to another student. Sadly, for those who are pre-med, they would have to take it.

I took this class as a senior so my viewpoint is a little skewered.  But as an engineering student, this one of the only classes I have taken at Yale where I felt the amount of preparation and work I've put in is directly proportional to how well I do in the class.  It's a good introductory course for first years, but if you're looking at taking you probably have to take it any way.  I would definitely take this over CHEM 163.
If it is not a requirement, I would not recommend a student to take this course because I feel that there are a lot more interesting science courses at Yale.

I realize most students take this class as a prerequisite, but I would gladly recommend this class to students looking to fulfill a QR requirement in a fun and engaging way. This class is all about putting in the work throughout the semester, and not just near midterms and finals. With a little bit of effort, it is pretty rewarding and lectures were always fun to go to.
Yes
I wouldn't recommend this course unless the student had to take it for their major.
Yes, I would recommend this class to another student. It was a very good introduction to chemistry.
Only take it if you need to
If you have to take general chemistry, this is a fine class. If you don't have to take it, then I wouldn't (because it's pretty rigorous and not as interesting as other classes you could be taking).
Yes. The workload was fair, and you will leave with greater confidence in your chemistry knowledge and problem solving abilities.
Yes, I would recommend this course.
I would recommend this course as it engages but is not impossibly difficult, students are very involved with their own learning and is a fun class
If you in the class its because you have to take it.
Yes; it will be helpful going forward in the sciences and a good foundation
Yes. The course is very well set up for learning and collaberation. There is always resources online or in person if you need help. The TA's set up ample review secessions for any test.

Yes, because it is a basic chem class.
It is not a flipped class, which is a good thing! However, you need to be on top of your things. Your performance relies on yourself. Don't count on the lectures to teach you the material.
I would recommend this class to anyone interested in the medical or chemistry fields as it gives a good base for the chemical processes.
If you plan on taking chemistry courses, it is a good class, but if you don't have an interest in chemistry I wouldn't recommend just taking the course.
I think it a great introductory course for chemistry and is a gateway to many other great classes offered
Yes for sure
I would. It's a very solid and clear introduction to chemistry. It's well organised, the Professor is very clear and fair.
I would recommend this course to another student because it provides a good basic foundation of chemistry necessary to be pre-med or a science major.

I would recommend this course to any student that understands the demands and how to study for this course beforehand. This class is an important foundation for many science courses so most people take this class just to get it over with.
yes especially if they are interested in majoring in a STEM course.
You should only ever take this course if it is in order to fulfill a requirement for a major.
Yes, I believe that this course will really set you up on a good path for college-level chemistry.
If one needs this class as a prerequisite, they should take it.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student, as it is an interactive way to learn the fundamentals of chemistry and how to apply them.
Yes
Yes I would recommend to another student, but mostly because it is a pre-requisite to most Chem and bio majors.
Take this class if you need it, not just to fill a distributional requirement.

I would recommend this course to another student. This course encourages you to think differently about the best way to study and it encourages collaboration. There is certainly a lot of work that needs to be put in to do well, but my foundation of chemistry is much stronger now that I've taken this course.

This course is honestly very hard if you haven't taken chemistry in a couple of years. It is a lot of work and many parts of the course are hard to understand. Really the only way to make it through is to have people in the class to study with and learn off of. Trying to endure this class alone will cause you to fail.
Sure, if you enjoy chemistry.
It was a good class so take it if you want but if you are planning on majoring on anything other than science and dont need it done take it
Yes only if they are premed though.
I would recommend this course. You have to do much of the learning yourself. I did not find the lectures very helpful.

I definitely would recommend this class to another student as it is a good introductory course and is heavily based on student learning. I think a student wanting to explore chemistry should definitely take this class.
Yes, does its job as an introductory chem class

General Chemistry provides a lot of foundational background for a lot of science classes and is a prerequisite for many, including a requirement for many majors. Great intro class where you learn a lot but also retain most of the information.

I would recommend this course. It is a good introduction to general chemistry. However, the student must be prepared to do much individual work through readings and self-motivation in order to get the most out of the class.
Yes, it's an interesting, fun-environment class.
Yes because most who take it must take the course.

No. Do not take it unless you have to. It is not organized to benefit student learning -- for instance, students are instructed not to collaborate on the weekly homework assignments, which impedes their ability to learn from them. While Prof. Holland is a good lecturer, clearly cares about student success and has provided helpful resources, and solicits student feedback, the class is not well arranged. The pace is often too fast and the class attempts to cover too much material in too little depth, as well as requiring the completion of tasks such as numerous practice questions and class attendance. These assignments grade students on their commitment to learning, which is their own responsibility and should not be graded.
I would recommend this course to another student, as I learned a lot in it.
I would not recommend this course to anyone who does not like Chemistry, or who would rather not learn Chemistry.

I would recommend this course to other students who also have a minimal/weak background in chemistry. Although the course is fast paced, there are many resources available for help which should be used as soon as possible. The lectures are also interesting as Professor Holland often includes demos.However, the class has a lot of reading and the p-sets can be very confusing especially as sapling doesn't offer examples.
Yes! Its a fine General Chemistry course and I have no real complaints about it
Yes I would
I would recommend this course for someone who wants to have a solid foundation in chemistry.
Sure. If youre interested in chemistry or need to take the course, I think its pretty well-taught and is very reasonable grading wise.
I would recommend this course to another student. There are many opportunities to learn and the material is very interesting.
Yes, I would definitely take this course to create a better foundation of chemistry.

I would recommend this course to those that require it for their major or pre-med requirements. This course is not easy and not one meant for fun learning. It's a general chemistry class intended to give a lot of information in a short amount of time.
This is a great introductory course to reinforce your understanding of the basics of chemistry.
This wasnt a bad course especially if you some chemistry background from high school.
Yes, this course is essential to those who plan to study chemistry because it teaches the basic concepts that are needed.
It is not a bad intro course in my opinion, should take it for an intro to sciences.
Yes, I think it gives a great foundation.
Only if necessary towards major.
Only as a pre med requirement
Yes, great lecture class. I would recommend going to section as well.
The classes are not very helpful so you will end up relying on the textbook anyways.
It's a prerequisite and necessary for a multitude of majors so I don't need to recommend it.

Yes, I would recommend the course to anyone who needs it for medical school/their major. If you want to take the course to fulfill the science credit, there are definitely better classes to do that. While the lectures do help explain a difficult concept sometimes, reading the book is your best bet at learning all of the material. Recordings of the lectures and the lecture slides are always posted online just in case you miss a lecture. The discussion sections can be very useful depending on your TA.
